title: Use negotiation tools and services
introduction:
The cheapest and easiest way to make child arrangements is for parents to negotiate between themselves.

There are several free online tools and services that can help parents reach an agreement.

Read more
body_copy:
There are free online tools and services that can help parents negotiate an agreement for their children without having to go to court.

Parenting plans

A parenting plan is a written or online plan that parents can use to prepare, discuss and agree child arrangements. A plan is flexible and not a legally binding agreement.

Using a parent plan:

  • helps parents know what’s expected of them
  • clarifies what’s been agreed (for example, where the children will live)
  • works as a reference for parents to go back to

There are good online parenting plans available:

Children and Family Court Advisory and Support Service (CAFCASS): https://www.cafcass.gov.uk/grown-ups/parenting-plan.aspx

Putting Kids First: http://www.splittingup-putkidsfirst.org.uk/home

Centre of Separated Families: http://www.separatedfamilies.info/home/parenting-apart/parenting-agreements/

Negotiating resources

The Negotiations Cycle tool allows parents to break down their negotiations into 4 stages.

GOV.UK has information on arranging child maintenance yourself that includes a child maintenance calculator.

Gingerbread has an arrangements factsheet that includes tips on making negotiations work.

Child Law Advice has a useful letter template if parents prefer to negotiate via letter or email.

The Separated Parents Information Programme is a course which helps parents understand how to put their children first while separating.

case_study.title: NEED A CASE STUDY
case_study.summary:
• Divorced
  • Children aged 7 years and 5 years
  • Combined total cost: £480
  • Total length of mediation: 2 weeks (3 sessions)
case_study.copy:
Things came to a head when 37 year-old Tom Jarvis moved out of the family home and into his new girlfriend’s flat. Tom and his wife Bryony, 35, both acknowledged that their relationship was over but arguments about contact with the children escalated to a point where both 7 year-old Declan and Luci-Anne, 5, were clearly being affected by the conflict.

Declan’s teacher had noticed he was being unusually disruptive and sullen at school, whilst Luci-Anne was having difficulty sleeping at night.

As part of his bid to ensure continuing contact with the children, Tom had approached a solicitor and it was she who had suggested mediation at their local NFM service as a possible way ahead.

Although Bryony admitted that she had been sceptical about the idea of mediation at first, she and Tom agreed to try it as a means of breaking the deadlock.

Their mediator, Elaine, helped them to understand each other’s position and their children’s needs, and after three meetings they managed to arrive at an amicable solution, which meant Declan and Luci-Anne were able to spend time with both mum and dad. Tom and Bryony also agreed to schedule a review of arrangements for six months later to see how things were going.
case_study.quote: Elaine Helped us to get on with making things work on a practical level. To some extent we had to put aside the angry feelings we had towards each other. This wasn't easy, but we both felt that doing so would be best for the children

usp_callout: Parents should consider this if they can still communicate with each other and already agree on the majority of issues.

cons.text: process heavily relies on parent co-operation

title: Mediation
introduction:
Parents can use a mediator if they can’t agree on some issues. Mediators won’t take sides or give legal advice but will try and help parents reach an agreement.

Parents must first meet with a mediator to check if mediation is right for them. This is called a Mediation Information and Assessment Meeting (MIAM).

Mediation works for most people - two thirds of couples who attend reach an agreement.

Read more
body_copy:
Parents must first meet with a mediator to check if it's right for them. This is called a Mediation Information and Assessment meeting (MIAM).

The mediator will explain:

  • how mediation works
  • the benefits
  • the likely costs
  • if the parents are eligible for free mediation through legal aid
  • whether it's right for the parents

Mediation usually takes place over several sessions, each lasting about 90 minutes. Parents can either attend together or separately.

If the parents reach an agreement the mediator will write it down. Parents can then ask a solicitor to make the agreement legally binding.

Agreements don't have to be legally binding but it can be useful if the arrangements are long and complex.

When mediation isn't suitable

Mediation isn't suitable in every case. Parents should seek alternative options if:

  • one of the parents has been a victim of domestic abuse or violence
  • there's a perceived risk to the child
  • the relationship between the parents has broken down completely (for example there's no contact)

cost.info:
The average cost of a mediation session is £80.

How many sessions you have depends on the amount of issues you want to discuss.

If you don’t work, or are on a low income, you may be able to get legal aid for mediation.

Check if you can get legal aid

resources.info:
National Family Mediation has more information on the mediation process and how it can benefit parents.

The Separated Parents Information Programme is a course which helps parents understand how to put their children first while separating.

Download a mediation information pack from the Ministry of Justice.

Advice Now has a guide to using mediation following separation.

cons.text: process heavily relies on parent co-operation

title: Collaborative Law
introduction:
Collaborative lawyers work with both parents to try and resolve their issues without having to go to court. After each parent appoints a lawyer everyone meets to negotiate face to face.

Negotiations are direct and efficient and give parents the opportunity to resolve issues in an amicable way.

Read more

title: Lawyer mediation
introduction:
Lawyer assisted mediation is slightly different to standard mediation. Parents still use the help of a mediator but both appoint their own lawyers who also attend.

The mediator is in charge and will direct the parents and their lawyers to help the process.

Read more

title: Solicitor negotiation
introduction:
Solicitor negotiation is like collaborative law in that both parties try to resolve issues out of court.

The difference is that the parents don’t meet to negotiate - this is all done by the solicitors.

Read more

title: Going to court
introduction:
Parents can go to court if they can't agree on arrangements. A judge will assess their case and make a decision for them.

Court should be the last resort for most parents as it can take a long time and be expensive. It's also often a stressful experience, especially for children.

Read more
body_copy:
Parents will need to apply for a court order if they can't agree arrangements. Before applying they should attend a Mediation Information and Assessment Meeting (MIAM), unless there's been domestic abuse.

To book a MIAM, parents must find a mediator.

Applying for a court order

GOV.UK has more information on how to apply for a court order.

When applying, each parent should give a brief summary of their own position and what they want to achieve from the hearing. This is sometimes known as a 'position statement'.

The court will set a date for a First Dispute Resolution Appointment (FHDRA). The date is usually around 4 weeks after it receives a court order application.

First Hearing and Dispute Resolution Appointment (FHDRA)

The court will ask an advisor from the Children and Family Court Advisory and Support Service (CAFCASS) to provide a report before the FHDRA.

A CAFCASS report includes:

  • a social services and criminal record check on the parents
  • details of current arrangements (this may include a record of how the child is feeling)
  • a summary of any other issues the court needs to be aware of

At the first hearing the court will see if there's still a chance of the parents reaching an agreement.

If the parents can reach an agreement the judge will write a final order setting out the details.

If there's no agreement at the first hearing

If the parents can't reach an agreement the judge will look at the issues they disagree on and set out a timetable for what will happen next.

GOV.UK has more information on what happens if there's no agreement at the first hearing.

cost.info: Depends on how complicated the case is.

less parental control - a judge will make the decision
